channel.title: Comments on: The ups and the downs continue
channel.description: my little place on the web

item.title: By: Sharon Cohen
item.dc:creator: Sharon Cohen
item.description: You doing so much fun I wish I could do all of this... Thanks man! -Sharon
item.content:encoded:
You doing so much fun
I wish I could do all of this…
Thanks man!
-Sharon

item.title: By: Stefan
item.dc:creator: Stefan
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/blog/2011/05/07/the-ups-and-the-downs-continue/#comment-4">John</a>.
Hi John,
My RTW packing list has been quite good so far as there isn't anything that I've immediately needed / missed, but there are a couple of things that I could have brought along - altitude pills, a lonely planet guide book (not the Footprint one I had), vaseline (sunburnt lips), sleeping shorts rather than relying on boxers... Its sundries mainly which I've been able to pick up here quite easily. The only thing I wished I had, but couldn't find - decent quick drying socks. Nights here are cold and it's nigh on impossible to dry clothes, that includes the quick-drying boxers and towel!
In terms of essentials, a familiar alarm clock (you have to wake at 5am so need to know you can wake), my spare camera battery (wish I'd brought 2 spares) and jeans! Jeans are big, bulky, heavy, terrible in the wet but they make you feel "normal" amongst the travel clothes wearing holiday makers. On that subject, I do wish I'd brought a some "normal" clothes though - I went with the cargo shorts & shirts as they are more verstatile for me and more usable on treks, but it does make you stand out a little in towns. You can tell the holiday makers as they are all wearing these sorts of clothes and someone asked if I worked at Machu Picchu yesterday as I "had a uniform". Still, clothes are cheap enough here so I'll grab a couple of t-shirts and jobs a good-un :)
In terms of things I shouldn't have brought - the big notepad (I've got a smaller one instead), the 30l rucksack (it's great for the Inca Trail and presumably buses, but it's usless to carry around).
I hope your travels go well! It's nerve-wracking, but there are some great people around and whilst it's tough, it's fun as well. I just need to get the ratio of fun up!
Stef
item.content:encoded:
In reply to John.

Hi John,

My RTW packing list has been quite good so far as there isn’t anything that I’ve immediately needed / missed, but there are a couple of things that I could have brought along – altitude pills, a lonely planet guide book (not the Footprint one I had), vaseline (sunburnt lips), sleeping shorts rather than relying on boxers… Its sundries mainly which I’ve been able to pick up here quite easily. The only thing I wished I had, but couldn’t find – decent quick drying socks. Nights here are cold and it’s nigh on impossible to dry clothes, that includes the quick-drying boxers and towel!

In terms of essentials, a familiar alarm clock (you have to wake at 5am so need to know you can wake), my spare camera battery (wish I’d brought 2 spares) and jeans! Jeans are big, bulky, heavy, terrible in the wet but they make you feel “normal” amongst the travel clothes wearing holiday makers. On that subject, I do wish I’d brought a some “normal” clothes though – I went with the cargo shorts & shirts as they are more verstatile for me and more usable on treks, but it does make you stand out a little in towns. You can tell the holiday makers as they are all wearing these sorts of clothes and someone asked if I worked at Machu Picchu yesterday as I “had a uniform”. Still, clothes are cheap enough here so I’ll grab a couple of t-shirts and jobs a good-un ðŸ™‚

In terms of things I shouldn’t have brought – the big notepad (I’ve got a smaller one instead), the 30l rucksack (it’s great for the Inca Trail and presumably buses, but it’s usless to carry around).

I hope your travels go well! It’s nerve-wracking, but there are some great people around and whilst it’s tough, it’s fun as well. I just need to get the ratio of fun up!

Stef

item.title: By: John
item.dc:creator: John
item.description:
Hi Stefan,
I came across your site while researching what I would need to take for my own round the world trip that I am planning to start this year.. I see that you are about a week into your trip now.. any immediate thoughts about the stuff you've taken - what is most essential, what you think you could have left behind, what you wish you had taken but didn't? It would be interesting to hear your opinion now, then again in a couple of months!
Hope you're doing well and experiencing many great things out there in world,
-John
item.content:encoded:
Hi Stefan,

I came across your site while researching what I would need to take for my own round the world trip that I am planning to start this year.. I see that you are about a week into your trip now.. any immediate thoughts about the stuff you’ve taken – what is most essential, what you think you could have left behind, what you wish you had taken but didn’t? It would be interesting to hear your opinion now, then again in a couple of months!

Hope you’re doing well and experiencing many great things out there in world,

-John
